text: LT Simpson OJ Simpson all right my
needle drops Anthony Fantan oh here
gonna do an LP review of the new guilty
Simpson album OJ Simpson but before I
jump too far to that I just want to say
quickly the website the needle drop com
is currently down I'm in the middle of
switching servers that's gonna happen
very soon hopefully the website is up
this coming week okay guilty Simpson's
rapper with some Detroit roots who
recently just a few years ago I want to
say came out with his full-length debut
ode to the ghetto and part of the reason
guilty has as much underground rap cred
as he does is he was championed by the
late and great producer J Dilla and what
makes his new LP so interesting to me is
that it's produced by none other than
mad lib right now 2010 mad libs in the
middle of a project where he's literally
releasing one new album a month of
instrumentals and loops and beats all
that kind of creating stuff that he does
not just that but the guy has worked
with Talib Kweli
of course MF doom or doom on the project
mad villain and he recently earned some
production creds on the new strong arm
steady album so with these two people
working together you have Gugu Susan and
madlib whose real initials are actually
oj so you bring it together you've got a
jason the first thing that really hit me
is that this project for Mad live at
least is somewhat of a callback to that
mad villainy album a lot of different
samples and styles and melodies are
hidden within the beats there are not a
lot of hooks here when guilty Simpson is
rapping is just a lot of straight
straight flows know sort of
interruptions sort of bringing in some
kind of catchy melody or something like
that there are a lot of psychedelic
effects a lot of studio trickery going
on and also there are quite a few
interlude sketches little comedic
moments when Madlib is putting a beat
together on this album he's doing it as
well as he's ever done it what I really
love about his style is that it doesn't
sound really
choppy or rigid or it doesn't really
sound all that looped though it's
clearly looped it really does have a
flow to it it really does have movement
to it as if the music you're hearing
played in the background is being played
in real-time doesn't sound like it's
just being kind of woowoo now in terms
of guilty Simpson I've heard ode to the
ghetto I've heard some tracks here
released before that but I'm not really
an expert on his guest spots in a lot of
places but still on this LP he pulls out
some of the best rhymes I've ever heard
him spit guilty just has some real
gangster aggression here this is just
some real tough guy rapping but it's not
the type of hip-hop where the lyricist
is just rapping about how much cooler he
or she is than you or how much more
money he or she has than you it's just
some badass rapping from a guy who's
clearly lived his life as a badass
guilty can be pretty relentless with
some of his rhymes but still there are
some moments where he'll throw in a joke
hear something really funny there kind
of breaks the tension a little bit too
he's got a really great flow throughout
this entire LP and throughout these 24
tracks here mad lib and guilty really do
produce some of their best work but
that's only when the two of them are
actually working I have one huge
gigantic gripe about this LP it just has
an extremely painful lack of balance
this LP is titled after guilty Simpson
but it doesn't really feel like a guilty
Simpson album it feels like a mad lib
album that guilty Simpson merely guests
on a couple times I know when it comes
to talking about rap albums and LPS in
the hip-hop genre a lot of people will
joke about you know how ridiculous some
of the interludes are maybe how good the
album would be without the interludes
however half of these tracks half of the
tracks literally half of the tracks are
either intros preludes outros plus are
interludes supposed to be short I mean I
know that four minutes isn't the longest
time in the world but a lot of the intro
moods on this album are longer than the
actual songs which is ridiculous
interludes intros outros that can add a
lot to an LP it could add context to a
song they can tease towards something
that's about to happen they can make
something funny they can make something
more serious they can give you an idea
as to what you're going to hear or give
you closure on what you just heard
however with 12 tracks being of that ilk
this LP really oversteps a boundary I'm
feeling a strong 5 to a light 6 on this
there are some tracks on here that
individually did make me think goddamn
these guys have to do another LP
I can't wait to listen to the next
guilty Simpson album however this thing
just detours way too much to feel like a
complete album if you're a guilty
Simpson fan if you're a mad lib fan mad
villany fan whatever let me know what
you thought of this love it
hate it and why anthony Fantan Oh guilty
Simpson Madlib OJ Simpson forever
you
